reviewText: I just wanted to point out that this version has excellent picture and audio (in Japanese) and great English subtitles. I'm very happy to add this to my collection.
Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD

reviewText: Despite the release of the rest of the Zatoichi movies in the US, Zatoichi #14 has remained unavailable.  Apparently, the rights are owned by a US company that considered a remake at one point, so the companies that released the rest of the Zatoichi films and TV series were unable to acquire the rights to volume 14.As others have noted, this is a nice copy of the film with good English subtitles.  The quality is comparable to all of the other recent DVD releases of Zatoichi films.However, given the licensing problems and the fact that this volume comes with a price stamped in Malaysian Ringgit, I suspect this is not a legal copy.  Malaysia is well known as a country where DVD piracy is commonplace.  Or, perhaps the US rights to the film are not exclusive.If the questionable provenance of this DVD doesn't bother you, it is a high quality copy of the film at a very good price.
Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD

reviewText: I have all of the other Zatoichi films and most of the Japanese TV series DVDs that have been released in the US in my DVD collection. I have waited a long time for a release of Zatoichi #14, Zatoichi's Pilgramage. To my knowledge, this film has never been released in the US. This is an import DVD with English subtitles. I can confirm that it played on my XBox 360 with no problem. I'm no DVD conisseur, but I thought this was a fine DVD and I really enjoyed watching it.As for the story, without giving too much away, Zatoichi has a spiritual crisis and longs to give up killing. He vows to go on a pilgramage to a series of temples until the gods give him answers to his questions. Before he even gets to the first temple, he winds up being forced to kill a man. He follows the man's horse to his home and there he finds the man's sister and yet another village suffering the depredations of an evil yakuza boss and his gang. The story goes on from there in typical and enjoyable Zatoichi fashion...If you enjoyed other Zatoichi films, I would definitely recommend this one. Not sure why this movie hasn't been released in the US. There are rumors on the internet, but nothing that I saw confirmed. Regardless, I found this film just as enjoyable as the other Zatoichi films. If you are a Zatoichi film collector, you'll probably want to grab this before it disappears.The DVD has no special features except a trailer for the film. The film is widescreen in Japanese language with English or Chinese subtitles. The English subtitles appear in white at the bottom of the film, but are removable, if you wish.To whoever owns the rights to this film, I will gladly also buy a US release of this film if one becomes available (hopefully with more extras, like maybe an explanation why this film was unavailable for so long.)
Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD

reviewText: ZATOICHI #14, a/k/a ZATOICHI'S OCEAN VOYAGE, a/k/a ZATOICHI'S PILGRIMAGE, a/k/a PILGRIMAGE (to those in the know, but to the elite it's a/k/a NUMBER 14), original title ZATOICHI UMIO WATARU, 1966, 89 minutes is a phantasmagoric and legendary entry in the original ZATOICHI film series. Undeservedly so, did I mention that? But it is good old Shintaro Katsu, a/k/a Katsushin to his friends, and so how can we complain?This edition is a Malaysian NTSC region 1 edition. I say enjoy it. In this episode, Ichi travels to one of the islands renown for its 88 shrines, and he vows to visit every one of them. He wishes to stop killing and at the very first shrine makes a vow to God that he will do so. At that shrine, there is a most classic soliloquy in which Ichi asks God, "Do the people I kill become angels?"Naturally, he can't keep the vow and finally says, "I guess I can't stop killing."All in all, it is an excellent if slightly less exciting entry in the film series; the opening sequence alone on the travel boat is well worth it. However, I review this, one of my favorite Ichi episodes, because of the stupid and inaccurate myths behind its lack of proper release in America. Shall we?Back in the 1980s, Chambara had the rights to the VHS releases of ZATOICHI episodes 1-15 and 17-20. When Chambara's VHS contract expired, they begged for the DVD release rights to no avail: those went to HVE Company with the exception of #14, which Chambara never had enough money to put out on VHS. Episodes 21-25 went to AnimEigo, and the final entry, titled ZATOICHI (a/k/a ZATOICHI 26, a/k/a DARKNESS IS HIS ALLY) would have to await some years' passage before it went to Media Blasters Tokyo Shock for DVD release.End of part one. Mysteriously, then, the Katsu Family did not want #14 released on DVD by anyone since it hadn't been released on VHS. Perhaps a marketing decision, perhaps not, it was always a decision belonging to Shintaro Katsu's heirs.MIRAMAX never had any rights to any ZATOICHI film and most probably never will. Enter Quentin Tarantino, who wanted to remakeZatoichi Vs the One- Armed Swordsmana/k/a ZATOICHI MEETS THE ONE-ARMED SWORDSMAN.Though Chambara never had rights to that episode, Tarantino asked them to contact the Japanese for remake rights. Why Tarantino did this is likely because he loved the Chambara VHS editions. Chambara invented Chambarama, which allows the subtitles to be seen in the black space beneath their widescreen picture and never infringed on the picture. In addition, Chambara did its own translations and the subtitles were exquisite.Chambara was told to tell Tarantino to take a hike, and more's the pity since Tri Star Pictures had obtained the rights to do a remake of their own, the infamously lousyBlind Furywith Rutger Hauer. Why? Who knows? Point is, #14 remained with Shintaro Katsu's family and wasn't ever released in the U.S.A., first due to lack of VHS funds; later due to unknown caprices. Tarantino threw up his hands by 1988 and gave up the idea of a remake.There you are, and can take it to the bank. Miramax never had any ZATOICHI film so certainly never held up its release. Disney never picked up a ZATOICHI film, as has often been stated. Understand one thing: companies do not buy and own films just to release them on video. There is a purely VIDEO RELEASE contract made in that event, and contracts do expire.That simple, folks. And that is the reason #14 is known by another name in the U.S.: THE HOLY GRAIL.
summary: And now the TRUE story of #14:

Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD

reviewText: Manipulation is the name of the game.  Zatoichi is, kind of, the victim of this piece as he is used both by a gang Boss and the villagers to do their bidding.  The feeling is both sides are, really, not very nice - frankly I found the farmers to be as backstabbing as the gangsters.  Also, the Blind Swordsman gives the impression that he knows this but is trapped between a rock and a hard place - he is the nice guy and has to try to do GOOD.It is dark with some spots of humor, such as the very smart horse and the opening scene in the ship does gives it a nice change of pace from the opening scenes in taverns most of the films start with.  Overall a very well made if gritty movie.  Enjoy!
Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD

reviewText: . . . But my MarketPlace seller sent me the wrong DVD. Now, it was good, maybe great, as are all Ichi flicks. The one I received is ZATOICHI'S OCEAN ADVENTURE.The seller's probably not at fault, but moviesfrom China can,logistically, have problems.Sad, because some the Chinese creative products are spectacular. A case in point: The best movie I've EVER seen, easily the top of my compulsive collector's list is WARRIORS OF THE RAINBOW, produced by John Woo, who's had a lot of Western success, yes?Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale [Blu-ray] - 4 1/2 hour International VersionAny version (2-hour version or the top-of-the-line four hour treasure) are worthy of you eyes and ears.Action beyond what you've ever seen, masterpiece cinematography you won't believe and moral/ethical/political/cross-cultural/spiritual topics which will leave you gasping and pondering for days if not months or years... All, re what's America into these days.I've only seen it 3-4 times, so I'm still hungry for more. FOUR AND A  HALF HOURS! AND there's no fill, just pure beautiful, provocative new ideas and insights. Sharp characterizations and humor. All clear, simple, staggering.And the most realistic battle action you may ever see, unless you enlist. Okay, pretty bloody, too. Like war is.
summary: I FOLLOW THE CLASSIC ADVENTURES OF ZATOICI, BUT...
Title: Zatoichi #14: Pilgrimage (1966, Japan) All-Region DVD
